The nightmares are back.

My mind has been pretty quiet for the past year. Once I figured out that Rogue really wasn't going to come back. I guess it was almost a kind of release for me. If she didn't come back, nobody would ever learn about what she'd seen. It didn't make them go away completely, but I didn't spend every night tossing and turning and waking up in a cold sweat.

At least they don't make me scream anymore.

Thing is...I can't even blame them on Rogue. I wouldn't, because they're my own creations, but they can't just trace to Rogue. I can trace them back to the students, mostly. We have around thirty students at the school right now. Every single one of them knows about the X-Men and what we do. A good half of those students want to be X-Men themselves once they have their powers under control. Worse, they look up to us as some sort of idols. Role models.

It scares the ever-loving shit out of me.

They don't know me. They don't know the things that I've done. Hell, the X-Men don't even know the things that I've done. But I'm no hero.

I remember those tunnels. In my dreams now, it's not just those I know were killed. I see the entire team dead, but not just them. The students are there too. Katie. Timothy. Jubilee. Eddie. All of them wearing the X. All of them in those damned tunnels.

He's there too, in the dreams. Comes up behind me just when I find Rogue, her eyes still open and accusing. He reminds me that it's my fault that they are dead. I led his men there, after all. It's my fault.

I'm sorry, chere.

I need to clear my head. Maybe some time in the Danger Room will help sort me out. Besides, I need to get that new uniform stretched out somehow.</lj-cut>

Who: Friday O'Reilly and Remy LeBeau Where: Mickey Finn's Pub When: A year and a half ago (in other words, backdated like WHOA...) What: One mutant private detective. One heartbroke Cajun thief. First meetings. Mickey Finn's is an old-fashioned kind of place. Wood rafters, thick wooden tables and a large bar off to the far side of the room serve to immediately give it a comforting atmosphere. A few rugs are scattered on the hardwood floor; age has worn off any designs and the general color scheme appears to have been reddish. A fireplace stands beyond the large bar, and tables are scattered in small clusters around the room. There is an air of a smoker's bar in the curtains. It is not an easy place to find, but it is not exactly hidden. Mickey himself is a large, burly man; a slightly balding redhead with a fierce mustache and kind blue eyes; with a penchant for smoking the most appallingly-smelling cigars in the world. Remy LeBeau is quite good at finding things that are hidden. Bars, however, are sometimes his forte. And right now, the Cajun thief needs a drink or five to stave the heartache and the guilt for another night. Maybe it's the smell of the cigars that draw him. They really aren't any worse than what Logan smokes, after all. He steps inside, looking a bit odd in his dark clothes, trench coat and sunglasses. No Logan. Oh well, he doesn't need anybody to drink with. Walking to the bar, he pulls out his wallet and drops a twenty on the bar. "Bottle of bourbon, s'il vous plait." There are quite a few people scattered about in the bar. An odd mix of mutants and non-mutants; there is a polite nod from one or two of them, or a bit of a glance at the stranger that appears at the door, but nothing else. There is an old piano in the corner, being banged on my an ugly, scrawny fellow doing his best Hoagie Carmichael impression. A freakishly tall man sits at a table playing cards with three short and buxom triplets, a priest sits beside the fireplace with a table full of laughing people, holding a smoke-ring contest. All in all, it is a quietly congenial place. At the bar sits a man who seems to be one of those mile-long-legs sort, skinny as a beanpole, and on the other side sits someone dressed in a large trench coat and a fedora, with a lot of reddish fur sticking out of places. A long cigarette seems jammed between the person's teeth. Mick nods, and gets him a bottle and a clean glass, setting it down on a napkin in front of Remy. "Merci, monsieur." Remy nods, taking the glass and bottle and leaving the twenty behind. He doesn't need the change, after all. He looks around, trying to find a good place to sit. His eyes drift over the triplets for a moment but he shakes his head. The priest isn't any better, really. No need for the whole 'soul saving' thing. Besides, he's not much good at smoke rings. After a moment, he drifts toward his fashion twin. "This seat taken?" He leaves off any honorifics, not knowing if the trench coated person is male or female. The bartender sweeps the twenty away with one massive hand, depositing his change with the other, and goes down to the other end of the bar to wait on someone, taking his god awful cigar with him. The person turns their head toward him, letting him see that the poor soul looks like a lovechild between a Wookie and a standard poodle. But the fuzz is a bit less dense on the face, and friendly spaniel brown eyes look at him. "Nope. It's all yours." The voice is female, and he can sort of see that through the shoulders as well. "Name's Friday." She nods politely to him. The name gets a cocked eyebrow. "Dat de first or last? 'Cause if it is de last name, I pray dat your parents didn' name you Josephine." Hey, he likes to watch reruns of Dragnet. He does take the seat. "Name's Remy, so dat we got de niceties out of de way." She huffs a laugh, switching the burning cigarette to the other side of her mouth with a flash of white teeth. "First name, though there's nothing better than Dragnet. Unless it's the Rockford Files, maybe. Friday O'Reilly. Nice to meet you, Remy." She extends a hand to shake his politely. "Careful of the back of my hand---don't hurt yourself." The back of her hand is covered with fur, but he can also see long shiny black lines sort of beneath the fur. "Remy LeBeau." His handshake his firm, fingers placed so that he doesn't get pierced. Though the spines do keep him from kissing her hand like he does with so many women. Releasing Friday's hand, he slides his sunglasses off to reveal those strange red-on-black eyes. "Pleasure is all mine, cher. Though I did prefer Star Trek." He opens the bottle of bourbon and pours a two-finger measure into the glass. She shakes his hand with a polite, firm graps. The fur is not too weird, as far as those things go, and she is also very careful so as not to pierce him with the flat spines. "Star Trek rocks," she agrees. "The original, I mean." She notices his eyes, definitely, but is a gent about it and raises her mug of Irish Coffee to him in a toast when he pours his bourbon. "To the days when things were far more simple." "Oh, oui. I can definitely drink to dat." He raises his glass and tinks it against hers. "Simpler days." Normally bourbon is a sipping drink. Remy, however, is not here for sipping. He tosses back about half the drink, shaking himself slightly as the warmth of the alcohol spreads down his throat. "So," he says after a moment, "what brings a lovely lady like you to a place like dis?" It's actually not a pick-up line, no matter how husky the drink has made his voice. He's just curious now. "Just lucky, I guess," she replies almost instantly to the age-old query. She takes a sip, licking the whipped cream carefully away from her upper lip. "Mickey Finn's seems to be one of those places that you find as you need it, you know? A while back, I really needed it. Life's kind of rough when you wear your own fur coat. PETA people hate you. So, I came here and stayed for the company. How about yourself?" "Dey're all nuts anyway." His smile is charming. "Me? Dis is my first time here. Needed to get 'way from de house for a while." Away from thinking about Rogue, mostly. Seattle. His old life before he became an X-Man. Hell, away from being an X-Man. The rest of the glass is finished and he busies himself pouring another. "It's a good place for that," she replies, nodding. "There's a few things you might want to know about this bar. The big guy behind the bar? That's Mickey. He doesn't put up with any mooks that come here. No drug pushers, no slimeballs, no pimps, none of that. Mutants are welcome as long as they behave themselves like the rest are expected to. No bar fights, no squabbles. And most of all, no prying. If he thinks anyone's prying into someone else's business, he'll toss 'em out on their ear himself. If anyone wants t'talk about what's hurtin' them, they'll find that everyone here is ready to listen. 'Shared pain is lessened, shared joy increased'. It's written on the mirror over there, see?" she points. "But anyone and everyone is welcome here. To hide, or to be found." His eyes track to the saying above the mirror. It brings a smile to his face. "Well, I don' do anyt'in' like drugs. Ain't a pimp." Lips curl slightly, like he's stepped in something nasty. "De slimeball...I t'ink my ex might 'gree wit' dat, but I would say she a bit biased." Thinking of Belle prompts him to knock back his second drink. The entire glass this time. "I promise I'll be good." Amusement in his eyes this time, along with that slight fuzziness that comes with drinking a little too fast. Hiding sounds good right now anyway. She nods as she watches him toss back his second drink, her gaze sharp. "I think we all have exes that would agree with the 'slimeball' tag," she states casually. "Yet here we are. Is that a N'awlins accent you've got? I went down there last year. Pretty place. The humidity raised hell with my hair, though." Remy is quite good at holding his liquor normally. He nods once. "Oui. Born an' raised." He sets his glass aside, giving himself a few minutes to deal with what's in his system before adding more. "I love de city. She's a beautiful lady. I just don't get back dere too often. De ladies, sometimes dey ain't always to happy wit' Remy, hein?" Which leads him back to Rogue and his hand twitches toward the glass, but he refuses at the moment. "Sometimes it's hard t'go back to a place where you grew up. Too many changes on both sides." She sips her coffee contemplatively, thinking about what he just said. "Sometimes...sometimes not being happy with someone doesn't mean what a guy thinks it means. And sometimes, it means even worse things. Relationships can be a real pain in th'ass sometimes." She stubs out her smoke into an ash tray, and sips at her coffee. "I'd drink to dat, but I t'ink I need to spread myself out a bit better." He raises an eyebrow, but remembers the rule about not prying, so doesn't ask the questions. "Yeah. De last girlfriend, she don' trust me." She got good reasons too, swamp rat, he reminds himself. "De ex-wife...dat's a story in an of itself and I shouldn't bore you wit' it." She chuckles, and pulls out a battered pack of Luckies from the inside of her trench coat. From what he can see, fur everywhere. Rusty-red. She offers him a smoke from the pack before taking one for herself. "In my experience, exes rarely trusted to begin with. Or else had it broken for a good reason, and everything goes to hell from that point on." She pulls out a World War 2 lighter, and lights his smoke if he took one, then her own. "Wouldn't bore me, Remy. Talking sports would bore me. But I'm not prying, mind. You may not see them easily, but I've got ears and know a thing or two about listening." He has his own smokes, but he'll never turn down a free one. He accepts the light and nods. "It's complicated. See, her brother tried to kill me on de weddin' night. Den I had to leave N'awlins right away." Basically thrown out of the Guild and New Orleans. He didn't even take the time to say good-bye to Belle. "She come after me a couple years later and I t'ought she was dead. Foun' out later dat she's okay, but she don' 'member me." He takes the cigarette from his lips and shakes his head. "Ever won'er just what you did to get sucked into de soap opera?" The fur on her face seems to move a bit in a sympathetic grimace. "That's hard. Would asking questions by prying?" Mickey, alerted by some sixth sense, looks over towards them. "I often wondered what I did to be stuffed in this awful sitcom, myself." For a moment, Remy seems to think it over. Finally, he takes a deep breath and blows out the smoke. "I'll tell you if de questions get too personal." The more he looks at her, the more he gets that she seems to remind him of something. He can't seem to remember what it is just yet, though. He's sure it'll come to him, though. She nods. "Deal." Mickey seems to relax, down at the other end of the bar. If she didn't remember you, why did she come after you a couple years later?" "I don' t'ink I'm makin' much sense. She came after me for some help. I gave de help, but t'ought she died in de helpin'. It was after dat dat I found out she was alive." And why she lost her memory is another thing that he really doesn't need to think about. He keeps his eyes away from the glass by force of will only. She nods, understanding a bit more, and she nods. "I get it. You'd already mourned for her loss, and then found out she was still alive. You had to deal with it all over again." She sips at her coffee before it starts to get too cold. "Is her brother still after you?" "Non. He's dead." Twice over. That would take too much time to tell too, so he leaves it at that. She nods, looking at him for a long moment. "Is this what's making you want to drink an entire bottle of bourbon tonight, Remy?" she blows out smoke from the side of her mouth. He raises an eyebrow, trying to decide if the question is too personal when things finally click. "Gossamer." Nonsequiter much? Her brows go up, and she gives a flash of teeth again around that cigarette. "Monsters are such interesting people. Only I'm not wearing sneakers, Cajun. If I am, better hide your rabbits." Remy tilts his head back and laughs. It feels good to do that again too. "Non, cher. De rabbits, dey better for eatin' anyway, hein?" He takes the cigarette from his mouth and taps off the ash. "I know, it seems weird, but...I t'ink it's de hair." "Not so weird," she replies, taking a deep drag on her smoke. "Since it's reddish and covers me, I mean. I just thank my lucky stars that my head isn't shaped like the top of a heart, or I'd have offed myself a long time ago." She gestures for Mickey's attention for another Irish Coffee, and glances to Remy. "Want to try an Irish Coffee? Make your bourbon last?" Mickey appears and gets her coffee, looking to Remy to see if he wants one. "Be a shame to do somet'in' to so pretty a head, too." Remy is Remy is Remy. He'll flirt, no matter what. "Sure. Dat sounds good." He nods to Mickey. She gives another huff of a laugh, amused at the flirting reflex. Mickey nods and brings an Irish Coffee to Remy, laced with real whipped cream and Bushmill's. "Your turn for a toast," she eyes Remy, holding her cup. He mulls it over for a moment, then smiles slightly. "To home. Wherever it might be." "Ahh. To home," Approval in her tone, and she nods firmly, clinking her cup to his before taking a sip. Ambrosia. "May I ask what you do now, Remy?" she asks after a moment or two of savoring the hot liquid. The real warmth of the coffee is a nice counterpoint to the artificial warmth of the bourbon. He grins, the whipped cream giving him a bit of a mustache and absolutely clashing with those eyes. "I'm in item reclamation." In a way, it's very true. It's just that the items he's reclaiming haven't always belonged to the people he's claiming them for, that's all. "An' I do some mutant rights stuff on de side." Also true. Not that the professor might agree with the way he's phrased it. She snickers, and nods. "Mhm. 'Items reclamation'. I know a few people that are fairly successful in that venture." She takes another sip, licking away the whipped cream, and leaning in towards him, speaking in a very soft whisper. "And is the mutants rights thing separate from being an X-Man, or a part of it? Don't worry. Elvis Himself could walk in here and order a drink and nobody would call the press. Like I said, this place is special." His eyes slide to her for a moment after she asks. He shakes his head. "Non. One in de same." His shoulders relax a bit. It's kinda like Jake's, only better because the mutants can be more open. Salem Center is a lot of things, but open-minded isn't always one of them. "An' I'm quite good at de reclamations, if I do say so myself." Third best thief in the world, last he'd heard. "It always pays to do a job well," she nods, sitting back on her stool, stretching her legs a bit. More fur. Ridiculously enough, flip-flops on her feet. "Personal pride in a job well done is often the best reward....although moola doesn't hurt to grease the wheels, either." He's not sure if this friendship will ever go beyond a single night of drinks. He's not attracted to her. Too close to Rogue leaving (again) for him to even think about it. But if it ever does, Friday is SO getting a pair of sneakers from him. Just for laughs. "A cher after my own heart." She grins, showing white teeth amidst the rusty fuzz. "Hey, what's work without personal pride, you know? No sense in doing a job if you can't do it well...oh, which reminds me." She pats her trench coat pockets, and pulls out a business card. "Friday O' Reilly" it states. There is a stylized drawing of an eyeball, complete with a fedora perched on top, and then an address and phone number. "My card." Remy takes the card, raising an eyebrow. "Friday O'Reilly, detective." He chuckles, tucking it into the inner pocket of his trench coat. "I'm 'fraid I don' got a card for eit'er job." Since thieves don't advertise, and the X-Men normally don't either. "Some jobs don't require them," she replies shrugging amiably. "It's the way of the world. Never a nine to five thing, is it? The most fascinating things always seem to happen in the dead of night." She takes another puff, and then blows out a smoke ring. Remy stubs out the end of his cigarette, reaching for his own pack this time. Marlboro Reds, which he offers. "Non. Never a nine to five t'ing at all. Eit'er one." He's going to be yelled at by Scott for being out all night again, but he doesn't care at the moment. "Al'ays been a night person myself. Prob'ly 'xplains why I never did dat well in school." She accepts with a nod of thanks, setting the smoke down. "Always been a bit of a night owl, myself. I did okay in school, but really didn't apply myself much. Didn't see the need until it was too late. Something about the nighttime, though. Seems more tolerant than the day. Besides, I like to sleep in." "Well, mos' my skills didn' come from de school house." Remy grins, sipping at his coffee again. "An' de girls was more int'restin' dan what de teacher was sayin'." Or he was simply thinking ahead to the pinch that night. With him, it could have been either. "In other words, the typical things of a normal kid," she nods, smoking for a moment. "I always tended to skip certain classes, which ended up biting me in the butt later on. But still. How can they expect kids to sit through geometry in spring?" "Now, geometry I didn' mind so much, though I paid more 'tention in trig. Knowin' how to work out angles has helped me a lot in bot' jobs." He also has an innate feel for angles, which helps him figure out card flights. "I tended not to be able to sit still t'rough history or literature, myself." She nods, grunting a bit. "Yeah, I never really thought about that much. But I can see how that'd happen. me, I was going to be a cop. I was always going to be a cop, ever since I can remember. So I paid attention to the things that I thought I'd need, y'know?" She takes a long drag on her Lucky, letting the smoke curl up and around her head. "But things happen. Life throws us curve balls." Remy nods, his smile a little crooked. "Mais oui. It certainly does." After all, who would ever think that a Cajun thief would find himself working the other side of things on the northern side of the Mason-Dixon line? Even if the group that he worked with wasn't exactly on the right side of the law, at least according to said law. She takes another sip of her coffee, nodding a bit, sitting in a comfortable sort of slouch. She shifts her positioning a bit, crossing her ankles the opposite way, which reveals that she is wearing what truly appears to be a kilt beneath the trench coat. "Wonder what the next year will bring," she muses. "Hopefully profit." She gives an amused glance over to Remy. Oh, is he ever easily amused. More easily when he's had alcohol, of course. The kilt gets a a raised eyebrow, but that's about it. "Pfft. Profit. I'll be happy if de next year bring me fewer bruises." She snickers. "I don't even bother hoping for that anymore," she replies. "Or else I'd have to get used to disappointment awfully fast. Besides, profit is what makes nursing those excess bruises worthwhile, you know. It serves as a financial sort of balm." "Don' worry 'bout dem anymore. 'Sides, never been good 'bout keepin' my resolutions anyway." As evidenced by the fact that he's usually back in Westchester before February. "I just start makin' de ones I know I can't keep, den I don' feel so bad when I can't." She looks at him for a moment, because they seem to be speaking about different things, and she grins with amusement. "You're speaking of New year's resolutions?" "Resolutions period, no matter when you make dem." It's really a bit late in the year for New Year's Resolutions, but what the hell. Besides, if he's not tracking the conversation, he'll just blame it on the drinks later. "De way I see it, dey just another reason to hope. You make a resolution and you hope it works out." Remy, on the other hand, has little to no hope left, ever. Which is why he keeps making the resolutions he can't keep. "So....are you saying you have no reason to hope?" She's actually surprised. Remy looks at her. He's looked so young most of the night, but he looks far older than his mid-twenties now. "I'm a soldier, cher. Have been for a long time now. Been fightin' long enough, ain't sure there's a drop of hope left to me, because I done given it all away. Every fight is so dat someone else can keep deir hope alive." He finishes off the coffee and frowns. "Maybe someday, I'll find a reason to hope 'gain." Damn it, he hates it when he gets like this. Usually if he's going to be this down, he's off on his own in the corner of a bar somewhere. Or, if he has to be with someone, it's usually Logan or Kurt, neither of which will try to draw him out. It is impossible to tell how old she is. That maddening fur tends to cover things. She is silent for a moment, looking at him, and sipping her coffee. "You will," she finally says. "But it'll happen when you least expect it." His look moves to encompass the bar, then he stands. "We'll see, Friday. For now, though, I t'ink dis Cajun best take his leave 'fore he starts bringin' de mood down, hein?" He picks up the bottle of bourbon, already paid for, and sets another twenty down. "You have a good night, Gossamer." He smirks slightly. The name does seem to fit. At least, it fits her looks if nothing else. "Didn't mean to chase you off, Remy," she replies. "You have a good night, too. Don't forget where this place is, now." She nods to him in a polite farewell, lighting up another cigarette. "Don' worry. I ain't been chased off. Just...sometimes, I'm better off drinkin' alone." He nods to her. "I be 'round, cher. Count on it." He pulls his glasses out and puts them on again before heading back out into the night. There had to be a dive hotel around here somewhere that he could sleep off the hangover he'd be getting after tonight. She knows the 'drinking by yourself' routine all too well. A final nod, and she exhales the smoke in a long gray plume, before stubbing the cigarette out and getting ready to head out herself. An X-man, with no hope and a broken heart. That's a downer for sure.

<lj-cut text="Look, t'aint gonna do either of us any good, ain't gonna do the house any good, us bein' like this.">
Just another round around the mansion, then she'd go back in. Really. Rogue was just about to turn the corner to the back of the school when she caught a faint red glow coming from one of the windows and had a sudden craving for a cigarette. She'd flown closer before she realized who it was likely to be, but she was well within his sight now. "Shit," she said softly.

Remy was sitting in his window, one leg on the sill, the other one still in the room. He drew in a breath, the cherry on the cigarette burning brighter for a moment before he took it out to knock off the ash. He looked up at Rogue, squinting a little, as though his eyes weren't quite focusing. His expression turned faintly resigned before he nodded. "Bonsoir, Rogue." Just Rogue. Not cher, not petite, not even Roguey. Just Rogue.

She couldn't fly away now. "Bonsoir Remy," she said with a nod. She moved a little closer, and she could practically smell the odor of liquor rolling off him. His room was quiet. Either Kitty and Bobby had fallen asleep or left. She waved a hand toward his cigarette. "You got 'nother one of those?"

That gets a raised eyebrow in response. "When you start smokin'?" That wasn't a no, though, as evidenced by the fact that he picked up his pack (right by his foot) and shook one out. He held it out for her, as far away from himself as he can. He's not expecting her to come any closer than she has to, after all. "I got a lig'ter in here. Somewhere." Accent is thicker tonight. Probably the alcohol.

Rogue approached to take the cigarette from him with a small shrug. "Just seemed to have picked it up," she said, casting a glance at the windowsill for a lighter. "I should quit, don't want to be a bad example for the kids." She glanced in the room. No Kitty, no Bobby. A bottle of bourbon within reach. 

Remy snorted slightly, putting his head back against the window jam. "So should I. Don' t'ink it's gonna happen anytime soon." Because they're all examples for the kids. And it wasn't like he was out getting drunk in front of them. The lighter turned out to be right next to Remy's foot as well. He shifted away slightly when she nears, bending over inside of the room. He came back up with a glass, one with a good measure of the bourbon in it, having switched from vodka a few drinks ago. Even so, he wasn't quite far gone enough to drink straight from the bottle.

She lit up, pulling back slightly to give him his space, left arm wrapped around her as she smoked. She watched him drink, unsure of what to say, or do. She'd promised to be civil, didn't mean she had to be friendly. Rogue smoked silently, keeping half an eyes on the grounds, half an eye on him.

"Sorry 'bout de War Room de ot'er day." He didn't look at her, staring down into his drink. "I was outta line." She probably never would have expected something like that out of him. He took a long drink, draining about half the glass in one swallow before he turned to look at her. "Dis ain't gonna be easy for ya, but I'll try not to make it any harder."

"You made a good point," she said grudgingly. She floated a little closer and reached for the bottle, tilting her head back as she swallowed, enjoying the burn. She set it back down on the windowsill deliberately, as if she were turning over a shot glass. "I promised Scott and Bobby I'd be civil," she said. She wasn't goin' to say 'thank you.'

"Merci." He can say thank you. He knew he was the one in the wrong, after all. The dark look to his eyes may bring to mind memories of the things that drive him to drink like this. Heartache, though in the memories she has it's mostly centered around Belladonna. Rogue, after all, wouldn't know how bad he was the night they parted in Seattle. There are darker memories too that cause this need to block the world out. To block the nightmares.

Rogue reached for the bottle again, then paused, taking a deep drag on her cigarette instead. There were already going to be enough sore heads in the morning, she didn't need to add hers to the mix. She studied him out of the corner of her eye, then sighed. She knew that look. She stubbed out her cigarette on the wall, then moved closer. "Look, t'aint gonna do either of us any good, ain't gonna do the house any good, us bein' like this. We need to come to some sort of workin' agreement or somethin."

He raised an eyebrow, head tilting to the side. "Oui. We do at dat." He set the glass aside and twisted slightly in the window to look at her better. With most people, it would have been uncomfortable. For him, it was just normal. "Any ideas? 'Fraid my head ain't 'actly right for t'inkin' right now."

She held back a snerk and a retort about his normal state of mind. "Can't say as I do," she said. "Guess we just ... we always do OK as teammates, no matter what else is goin' on." That's about all she had to offer right now. To work as his teammate. To consider him as such 24 hours a day.

Remy nodded, knowing that it was the best he could hope for unless he was actually able to tell her about the tunnels. "Teammates. Dat's good enough." Definitely good enough to keep them from trying to kill each other in the halls. Maybe enough to keep either one of them from spending their nights drinking. Okay, enough to keep him from doing it, maybe.

Rogue picked up the bottle again, clinking it against his glass before she took another shot. "Teammates."

Don't normally chain-smoke like this, but I'm nervous, I guess. Shouldn't leave so much time between writing in this thing. Too much happens and I get behind and end up eating up three pages trying to get my thoughts down. [English]Battle tomorrow today (just checked my watch and it's 1 am). I'm going to leave this journal in the drawer, but it'll be unlocked. If something happens...whoever finds this, please tell Rogue that there's a safe deposit box in New Orleans. My father can tell her which bank if she doesn't know already. Some of my other journals are there. The ones that can tell her everything she needs to know. And...and let her know that I'm sorry for being too chicken to tell her myself.

Left the mansion the day after Christmas. For good, this time. I think I start every year off with that resolution. I come to New Orleans to meet with Poppa, find out where I stand with Belle. Pull a couple of jobs because I can. And, after a few weeks, break the damned resolution and go right back. Need to go Christmas shopping. This time, I'm making a resolution and sticking with it. Remy LeBeau sat back and slammed the journal shut. His teammates [former teammates] would be surprised to find that he wrote a journal. And not even one on a computer, but in a leather-bound book. Tante Mattie had given him one for his first Christmas at age ten. She had given him one every year since then. Some years he never wrote it in. Other years, he had to buy new ones because he ran out of room. He threw down the pen and stood up, walking away from the desk. His New Orleans home was on the very outskirts of the city. Mardi Gras was less than a month away. The Guilds would be busy and even he wouldn't be denied a chance to take part in the revelry. People were careless when they got drunk. Anything could happen. He tried to remember the last time he'd been to a proper Mardi Gras. It had been a while. It would be good to be back and see one, to participate in all that the city had to offer up in the spirit of the carnival. "And if you come 'cross a couple of Assassins cuttin' some poor man up, what you do den, Remy?" he muttered to himself, then sighed. He would stop them. Because he had seen too much death to just ignore it when it happened around him. He put his forehead to the window for a moment, feeling the cool glass against his skin. Then he turned and walked back to the desk. He didn't sit down, though. Instead, he reached across it and picked up a pair of tickets to the BeauSoliel concert in three days. Gifts from Scott Summers aka Fearless Leader. He stared at the tickets for a moment, then sat down and opened the journal to the first page again. He looked it over, picked up the pen and put a line across the page. Can't keep that one. Damn it. Maybe next year. Resolution this year: Stop letting the past hold me back. And punch Sinister in the jaw if I ever see him again. Satisfied, he closed the journal and tucked it away into a locked desk drawer. Nobody would get to it there. If there was one thing a thief knew about, it was security.
